columns.text:
In this exercise, we will examine some essential characteristics of bonds (and equities in general)- effective annual interest rate, annual percentage rate, and the present value of an annuity.

Let's get started!

**Let's start by explaining the key terms of this exercise.** Effective annual rate (EAR) is the interest rate that takes compounding into consideration. Investors use it to compare different equities that calculate the annual interest with different compounding periods. Annual percentage rate (APR) is the yearly interest rate expressed in percentages that an individual needs to pay for borrowing money. $$\text{APR} = \Bigg(\Big(1 + \text{EAR}\bigg)^{\dfrac{1}{n}} - 1\Bigg) \times n \tag{1}$$ Where EAR - Effective Annual Rate n - Number of compounding periods $$\\[15pt]$$ The present value of an annuity (PVA) is the amount of money required today to finance annual payments in the future. We can calculate it by using the below formula: $$\text{PVA} = P \times \dfrac{1-\bigg(\dfrac{1}{1+r}\bigg)^n}{r} \tag{3}$$ Where: P - Payment n - Number Of Compounding Periods r - Interest Rate

The exercise text provides us with the following information: 

1. The cost of flowers is $7.
2. The effective annual rate is 6.4%.
3. The price of flowers increase by 3.7%. Hence, the yearly inflation rate for flowers is 3.7%.
4. Joe is expected to live another 30 years and every year has 52 weeks.

Notice that we have inflation happening. Hence, we cannot use the effective annual rate that is provided in the exercise text. This rate is nominal, so we need to find the real effective annual rate as it considers inflation. We can use the Fisher equation to find the real effective annual rate (EAR) : $$ \text{Nominal EAR} + 1 = (1 + \text{Real EAR}) \times (1 +\text{Inflation Rate}) \tag{1} $$

By inputting into Eq.$(1)$ the nominal effective annual rate and the inflation rate given in the exercise text, we get the following real effective annual rate: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Nominal EAR} + 1 &= (1 + \text{Real EAR}) \times (1 +\text{Inflation Rate}) \\[20pt] 6.4\% + 1 &= (1 + \text{Real EAR}) \times (1 +3.7\%) \\[20pt] \text{Real EAR} &=\frac{6.4\% + 1 }{1 +3.7\%} - 1 \\[20pt] \text{Real EAR}&= 2.603\% \end{aligned}$$

To find the annual percentage rate, we'll input the given values into Eq.$(1)$: $$\begin{aligned} \text{APR} &= \Bigg(\Big(1 + \text{EAR}\bigg)^{\dfrac{1}{n}} - 1\Bigg) \times n \\[15pt] &= \Bigg(\Big(1 + 2.63\%\bigg)^{\dfrac{1}{52}} - 1\Bigg) \times 52 \\[25pt] &= 2.596\% \\[10pt] \end{aligned}$$ But we must find the weekly interest rate instead to solve this exercise. To find the weekly interest rate, we will divide the annual percentage rate by the number of weeks in a year ($52$): $$\begin{aligned} \text{Weekly Rate} &= \dfrac{2.496\%}{52} \\[15pt] &=0.048\% \end{aligned}$$

Now, we have all the information we need to calculate the present value of all the future flower costs. By inputting the values into Eq.$(3)$, we get the present value of an annuity (PVA) for the flowers: $$\begin{aligned} \text{PVA} &= \$7 \times \dfrac{1-\bigg(\dfrac{1}{1+0.048\%}\bigg)^{30\times 52}}{0.048\%} \\[15pt] &= \$7 \times \dfrac{1-(0.99952)^{1560}}{0.048\%} \\[15pt] &= \$7 \times \dfrac{0.52715}{0.048\%} \\[15pt] &= \$7,687.60416 \end{aligned}$$

Let's recap what we have done in this exercise! First, we explained the key terms of this exercise. Then we adjusted the effective annual rate (EAR) for inflation. We did this by using the Fischer equation. Then we calculated the weekly interest rate by using the annual percentage rate (APR) and dividing it by the number of weeks in a year. Finally, by using the values we figured in prior steps, we calculated the present value of an annuity.
